channel.title: Posts on Mitch Beebe
channel.description: Recent content in Posts on Mitch Beebe

item.title: Webcam Image Classification
item.description: As I mentioned in my “Hello World” post, I’m fascinated with computer vision. I’m still in the process of writing up a post about the image classification mobile app that I made to detect whether my iPhone camera is pointing at my dog or not. While doing so, I figured out how to incorporate Tensorflow/Keras ML models into an RMarkdown blog post and decided to share this in the meantime. I was thinking I’d need to embed a Shiny application with an upload photo UI, pre-loaded model, and image display, but to my surprise, it can all be done with a few JavaScript code chunks in a .

item.title: Webscraping NHL Data with RSelenium, Part 2
item.description: NHL-WHA merger With the absorption of four teams from the World Hockey Association in the 1979–1980 season, a new playoff system was introduced where 16 of the league’s 21 teams would qualify for postseason play. The four division winners would qualify for the playoffs while twelve wildcard positions rounded out the sixteen teams. At the beginning of each round the teams were seeded based on their regular season point totals, with the preliminary round being a best-of-five series while all other playoff series were best-of-seven.

item.title: Raspberry Pi Dog Monitor
item.description: Crate-training a puppy can be tough and a total surprise when you come home to find that they’ve torn up their bed, had an accident, or worse, broken free and vandalized your apartment. My dog, Harper, has done all three, but has since learned to love her cozy den. As I teased in my “Hello World” post, I built a dog monitor using a Raspberry Pi to see what she was up to while I was gone.

item.title: Webscraping NHL Data with RSelenium, Part 1
item.description: I love hockey. I also love data science. What’s better than merging the two and learn how to use RSelenium in the process? A while ago, I wrote some web-scraping code to find the NHL standings as of Novermber 1st (roughly one month into the season). I was doing this in order to determine if a strong start to the season was related to end-of-season success. Fortunately, the website dropyourgloves.

item.title: Hello World
item.description: R Markdown This is my first post! This website was developed with R Markdown, Blogdown, Hugo, and served via Netlify. I tried hosting this on GitHub Pages, but had difficulty with Jekyll and the R Markdown format. Having read about Blogdown, I’m making the transition. So far this is great. I can embed R code like this: summary(cars) ## speed dist ## Min. : 4.0 Min. : 2.00 ## 1st Qu.
